did.abstract: University of Michigan senior honors society with initiation rites, costumes and other rituals based on supposed Native Amerincan traditions; records include chronological "tribe" files, minutes of meetings, topical files, visual materials, and printed materials.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The record group was donated in a number of accessions from various sources, the majority from Michigamua in 1993. Donor No. 8149

accessrestrict.p: The record group is open for research.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: item, folder title, box no., Michigamua Records, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Michigamua is one of the best-known senior honor societies for men at the University of Michigan and is dedicated to bringing together outstanding upperclassmen to foster a loyalty to the university and to promote good class fellowship (Box 3, Folder: Topical Files, History and Traditions, General; Document: "The Great Charter of the Tribe of Michigamua"). Michigamua was created in Spring 1901 by a group of students belonging to the Class of 1902. These students, all of whom attended the Literary College (now the College of Literature, Science, and the Arts) and met nightly to study together, had formed The Hot Air Club in Fall 1900. This club was expanded to include students from other units in Spring 1901 and, after much research into Native American lore, the name of the club was changed to Michigamua. Selection for membership was based upon loyalty to the university and to their class, as well as prominence in an activity that brought credit to both (William F. Temple The Founding of Michigamua, p. 16). Members often held positions of note in student government or on student publications, or excelled in athletics or scholastic endeavors. With the Tribe of 1903, it was decided to limit the number of active members, or "Fighting Braves," to no more than twenty-five men.

A student is invited to join Michigamua in the winter term of his junior year by means of a tradition of "tapping" which occurs late at night. The student then undergoes the rites of initiation on "Rope Day." All members are assigned a nickname, such as Babbling Brook, intended to reflect a characteristic, trait, or activity of a brave. The active tribe meets on a regular basis in the "Wigwam," located in a tower of the Michigan Union. Alumni of Michigamua are referred to as "Old Braves" and remain active by means of the Old Braves Council which advises the active tribe on various matters. Occasionally a prominent member of the faculty or administration may be invited to join Michigamua as an honorary member or "Honorary Sachem."

scopecontent.p: The records of Michigamua consist of four linear feet and six outsize folders and span the years from its creation in 1902 to the present. They document the activities of past Michigamua tribes, the role of the Old Braves within the society, and the development of Michigamua traditions. The records are divided into five series: Chronological Tribe Files, Meeting Minutes, Topical Files, Visual Materials, and Printed Materials.

controlaccess.head: Subjects:
controlaccess.corpname: University of Michigan--Students--Social life and customs.

scopecontent.p: The Chronological Tribe Files (.8 linear feet) span the years 1908 to 1992 and contain materials generated and received by a tribe during their active year. Such materials include membership lists, correspondence with Old Braves and the Old Braves Council, initiation plans, proposals for Honorary Sachems, and annual financial reports.

The correspondence with Old Braves is especially interesting both for its historical anecdotes, as well as for its expressions of concern about and support for various campus issues. Historical anecdotes and references are scattered throughout the Chronological Tribe Files. For example, the folder "Tribe of 1955" contains an historical account of the Michigamua pin and ring. Acquisition of the totem pole is documented in the folder "Tribe of 1957." A history of Rope Day can be found in the folder "Tribe of 1958."

Among the campus issues examined in the correspondence are: plans for a cooperative bookstore in the Michigan Union in the "Tribe of 1949" folder; the ban on student automobiles in the "Tribe of 1953" folder; women cheerleaders in the "Tribe of 1958" folder; and student unrest in Tribe folders of the late 1960s and early 1970s. Also, the folder "Tribe of 1973" contains documentation of the complaint filed with the Michigan Civil Rights Commission against Michigamua for its portrayal of Native American traditions. The folder "Tribe of 1977" contains documentation of the complaints brought against Michigamua for alleged violations of Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and of Title IX of the Education Amendments Act of 1972 relating to Michigamua's exclusion of women.

The Meeting Minutes (1.2 linear feet) are arranged chronologically by academic year and date from 1906/07 to 1986/87. Except for a ten-year gap from 1975/76 through 1984/85, the meeting minutes are fairly complete. They are mostly handwritten and seem to be primarily administrative in content. It should be noted that Michigamua has its own method of recording dates: days are referred to as "Sleeps," months are "Moons," and years are "Hunts." Originally, the months were referred to numerically, i.e., First Moon, Second Moon, etc; however, by 1907, Michigamua had substituted new names for each of the months. January, for example, is the Moon of New Hearts. A list of the Moons can be found at the beginning of the 1915/16 Meeting Minutes.

The Topical Files series (.8 linear feet) is rich in information regarding the early history of Michigamua and the development of traditions and customs. Other topics well documented are the creation of the Wigwam and the activities of the Old Braves.

did.unittitle: Correspondence of William "Billy Bowlegs" Temple with Old Braves regarding Michigamua history 1933-1935, 1942-1948

odd.p: includes constitution of The Hot Air Club
includes preliminary sketches of Fielding Yost Memorial

did.unittitle: Detroit, Chicago, and Lake Erie Councils 1948-1949, undated

scopecontent.p: The Visual Materials series (.2 linear feet, outsize box, and six outsize folders) is divided into two subseries: Photographs, and Sketches and Drawings. The Photographs subseries, which includes four outsize folders, dates from 1906 to 1984. Images portray Michigamua members and activities. The Sketches and Drawings subseries consists of one folder of undated sketches of Michigamua logos and an outsize folder of blueprints from 1933 relating to the Wigwam.

odd.p: includes six black and white positive prints of: Henry C. Adams, undated; "Battle Finder" Bartelme, undated; "Slu Foot" Goetz 1920, W. B. Rea, undated; "Heap Think" Wenley 1906, one unidentified, undated

scopecontent.p: The Printed Materials series (1 linear foot) is divided into two subseries. The first includes directories, newsletters such as Tower Talk of Michigamua, and programs from the anniversary pow wows and rope days. The second subseries is made up of directories, newsletters, and programs from the alumni groups of Michigamua such as the Old Braves Council, the Michigamua Braves of Fort Detroit, the Lake Erie Wigwam in Cleveland, and various Michigamua classes.
